messageBody:
Chuck Peck wrote:
>
>
> It's my personal belief that the dictionary I created was only a guide
> and learning tool. I also believe that QS should be used in a way that
> reflects each individual's unique accent. The over all word form, should
> only be a guide to our reading.
>

This topic really can be useful. While trying to learn QS, I have
thought about this problem. If users just write the way the word sounds
to them, then it would make reading harder. We recognize words by sight.
(For example, notice how much harder this is to read: we recanize
wurdz bi site.) Seeing a word spelled exactly the same way gives us a
shortcut. I know that Shakespeare spelled the same words different ways,
but I'm thinking that his spellings didn't vary much from the norm.

However, even if it is better to have each user spell the word in the
way he pronounces it, a bigger problem arises. Does the user actually
even know how he pronounces the word, or is he making a mistake? For
example, I might spell the recognize as Roar Ed Kick On Nun If Zoo. I
would have made two mistakes in thinking the second vowel was "On" and
the last vowel was "If." In fact, the second vowel should be Ado and the
last vowel should be Ice. I might fool myself into thinking I need "On"
and "If" because I have seen them spelled that way my whole life. But
certainly I *don't* pronounce them this way. I can't say that I should
spell a word the way I pronounce it when I am mistaken in my
pronounciation.

Put another way, if a QS writer wants to spell a word different than
standard pronounciation, then he should be aware he is doing so.

I think what would be really useful is to map each QS letter to an IPA
symbol. (I have actually already done this already and will post my
chart when I finish it right.) We can agree to let each user have his
own spelling, but we should have absolutely strict rules about what
sound each QS letter represents. We can spell "pot" two or even three
different ways, but I think we should agree that the "On" (or "Ox")
sound represents the most open, rounded, back vowel--no exceptions.

Paul
